**John Barry Prendergast** ,
[OBE](/wiki/Officer_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire "Officer of the Order
of the British Empire") ([/ˈbæri/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English");
3 November 1933 – 30 January 2011)[1][2] was an English composer and conductor
of film music. He composed the scores for 11 of the _[James
Bond](/wiki/James_Bond_in_film "James Bond in film")_ films between 1963 and
1987, and also arranged and performed the "[James Bond
Theme](/wiki/James_Bond_Theme "James Bond Theme")" to the first film in the
series, 1962's _[Dr. No](/wiki/Dr._No_\(film\) "Dr. No \(film\)")_. He wrote
the Grammy- and Academy Award-winning scores to the films _[Dances with
Wolves](/wiki/Dances_with_Wolves "Dances with Wolves")_ and _[Out of
Africa](/wiki/Out_of_Africa_\(film\) "Out of Africa \(film\)")_ , as well as
the theme for the British television cult series _[The
Persuaders!](/wiki/The_Persuaders! "The Persuaders!")_ , in a career spanning
over 50 years. In 1999, he was appointed OBE at [Buckingham
Palace](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace "Buckingham Palace") for services to music.

Born in [York](/wiki/York "York"), Barry spent his early years working in
cinemas owned by his father. During his [national
service](/wiki/National_service "National service") with the British Army in
Cyprus, Barry began performing as a musician after learning to play the
trumpet. Upon completing his national service, he formed his own band in 1957,
[The John Barry Seven](/wiki/The_John_Barry_Seven "The John Barry Seven"). He
later developed an interest in composing and arranging music, making his début
for television in 1958. He came to the notice of the makers of the first James
Bond film _[Dr. No](/wiki/Dr._No_\(film\) "Dr. No \(film\)")_ , who were
dissatisfied with a theme for [James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond "James Bond")
given to them by [Monty Norman](/wiki/Monty_Norman "Monty Norman"). This
started a successful association between Barry and [Eon
Productions](/wiki/Eon_Productions "Eon Productions") that lasted for 25
years.

He received many awards for his work, including five [Academy
Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards"); two for _[Born
Free](/wiki/Born_Free "Born Free")_ , and one each for _[The Lion in
Winter](/wiki/The_Lion_in_Winter_\(1968_film\) "The Lion in Winter \(1968
film\)")_ (for which he also won the first [BAFTA Award for Best Film
Music](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Film_Music "BAFTA Award for Best Film
Music")), _Dances with Wolves_ and _Out of Africa_ (both of which also won him
[Grammy Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award")). He also received ten
[Golden Globe Award](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden Globe Award")
nominations, winning once for [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Golden Globe Award
for Best Original Score") for _Out of Africa_ in 1986. Barry completed his
last film score, [_Enigma_](/wiki/Enigma_\(2001_film\) "Enigma \(2001
film\)"), in 2001 and recorded the successful album _[Eternal
Echoes](/wiki/Eternal_Echoes "Eternal Echoes")_ the same year. He then
concentrated chiefly on live performances and co-wrote the music to the
musical _Brighton Rock_ in 2004 alongside [Don
Black](/wiki/Don_Black_\(lyricist\) "Don Black \(lyricist\)"). In 2001, Barry
became a Fellow of the [British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and
Authors](/wiki/British_Academy_of_Songwriters,_Composers_and_Authors "British
Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors"), and, in 2005, he was made a
Fellow of the [British Academy of Film and Television
Arts](/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts "British Academy of
Film and Television Arts"). Barry was married four times and had four
children. He moved to the United States in 1975 and lived there for the
remainder of his life until his death in 2011.

##
Biography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Biography")]

### Early life and
education[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early life and education")]

Barry was born John Barry Prendergast, in [York](/wiki/York "York"), England,
and was the son of an English mother and an Irish father. His mother was a
classical pianist. His father, John Xavier "Jack" Prendergast, from
[Cork](/wiki/Cork_\(city\) "Cork \(city\)"), was a
[projectionist](/wiki/Projectionist "Projectionist") during the silent film
era, who later owned a chain of cinemas across [northern
England](/wiki/Northern_England "Northern England").[3][4][5] As a result of
his father's work, Barry was raised in and around cinemas in northern
England[3] and he later stated that this childhood background influenced his
musical tastes and interests.[4] Barry was educated at [St Peter's School,
York](/wiki/St_Peter%27s_School,_York "St Peter's School, York"), and also
received composition lessons from [Francis
Jackson](/wiki/Francis_Jackson_\(composer\) "Francis Jackson \(composer\)"),
Organist of [York Minster](/wiki/York_Minster "York Minster").[4]

###
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Career")]

Serving in the [British Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army"), Barry spent
his national service playing the trumpet.[6] During his army service, he took
a correspondence course (with [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") composer [Bill
Russo](/wiki/William_Russo_\(musician\) "William Russo \(musician\)")); he
also worked as an [arranger](/wiki/Arrangement "Arrangement") for the [Jack
Parnell](/wiki/Jack_Parnell "Jack Parnell") and [Ted Heath's
Orchestra](/wiki/Ted_Heath_\(musician\) "Ted Heath \(musician\)"),[7] and
formed his own band in 1957, [the John Barry Seven](/wiki/The_John_Barry_Seven
"The John Barry Seven"),[8] with whom he had some hit records on [EMI's
Columbia](/wiki/Columbia_Graphophone_Company "Columbia Graphophone Company")
label. These included "Hit and Miss", the theme tune he composed for the BBC's
_[Juke Box Jury](/wiki/Juke_Box_Jury "Juke Box Jury")_ programme, a cover of
the [Johnny Smith](/wiki/Johnny_Smith "Johnny Smith") song "[Walk Don't
Run](/wiki/Walk_Don%27t_Run_\(song\) "Walk Don't Run \(song\)")", and a cover
of the theme for the United Artists western _[The Magnificent
Seven](/wiki/The_Magnificent_Seven "The Magnificent Seven")_.

By 1959 Barry was gaining commissions to arrange music for other acts,
starting with a young trio on Decca, coincidentally called the Three Barry
Sisters, though unrelated both to Barry and the more famous Barry Sisters duo
in America.[9] The career breakthrough for Barry was the BBC television series
_[Drumbeat](/wiki/Drumbeat_\(TV_series\) "Drumbeat \(TV series\)")_ , when he
appeared with the John Barry Seven. He was employed by [EMI](/wiki/EMI "EMI")
from 1959 until 1962 arranging orchestral accompaniment for the company's
singers, including [Adam Faith](/wiki/Adam_Faith "Adam Faith");[10] he also
composed songs (along with [Les Vandyke](/wiki/Les_Vandyke "Les Vandyke")) and
scores for films in which Faith was featured. When Faith made his first film,
_[Beat Girl](/wiki/Beat_Girl "Beat Girl")_ (1960), Barry composed, arranged
and conducted the score, his first. His music was later released as the UK's
first soundtrack album.[11]

Barry also composed the music for another Faith film, _[Never Let
Go](/wiki/Never_Let_Go "Never Let Go")_ (also 1960), orchestrated the score
for _[Mix Me a Person](/wiki/Mix_Me_a_Person "Mix Me a Person")_ (1962), and
composed, arranged and conducted the score for _[The Amorous
Prawn](/wiki/The_Amorous_Prawn "The Amorous Prawn")_ (also 1962). In 1962,
Barry transferred to [Ember Records](/wiki/Ember_Records_\(UK_label\) "Ember
Records \(UK label\)"), where he produced albums as well as arranging
them.[12]

These achievements caught the attention of the [producers](/wiki/Film_producer
"Film producer") of a new film called _[Dr. No](/wiki/Dr._No_\(film\) "Dr. No
\(film\)")_ (1962) who were dissatisfied with a theme for [James
Bond](/wiki/James_Bond "James Bond") given to them by [Monty
Norman](/wiki/Monty_Norman "Monty Norman"). Barry was hired and the result was
one of the most famous signature tunes in film history, the "[James Bond
Theme](/wiki/James_Bond_Theme "James Bond Theme")". (Credit goes to Monty
Norman, [see here](/wiki/James_Bond_Theme#Authorship_of_the_"James_Bond_Theme"
"James Bond Theme").) When the producers of the Bond series engaged [Lionel
Bart](/wiki/Lionel_Bart "Lionel Bart") to score the next James Bond film
_[From Russia with Love](/wiki/From_Russia_with_Love_\(film\) "From Russia
with Love \(film\)")_ (1963), they discovered that Bart could neither read nor
write music. Though Bart wrote a title song for the film, the producers
remembered Barry's arrangement of the James Bond Theme and his composing and
arranging for several films with Adam Faith. Lionel Bart also recommended
Barry to producer [Stanley Baker](/wiki/Stanley_Baker "Stanley Baker") for his
film _[Zulu](/wiki/Zulu_\(1964_film\) "Zulu \(1964 film\)")_ (1964).[13] Bart
and Barry worked together in the film _[Man in the
Middle](/wiki/Man_in_the_Middle_\(film\) "Man in the Middle \(film\)")_.

This was the turning point for Barry, and he subsequently won five [Academy
Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards") and four [Grammy
Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award"), with scores for, among others,
_[Born Free](/wiki/Born_Free "Born Free")_ (1966), _[The Lion in
Winter](/wiki/The_Lion_in_Winter_\(1968_film\) "The Lion in Winter \(1968
film\)")_ (1968), _[Midnight Cowboy](/wiki/Midnight_Cowboy "Midnight Cowboy")_
(1969) for which he did not receive an on-screen credit.[14] and _[Somewhere
in Time](/wiki/Somewhere_in_Time_\(film\) "Somewhere in Time \(film\)")_
(1980).[2]

Barry was often cited as having had a distinct style which concentrated on
lush strings and extensive use of brass. However he was also an innovator,
being one of the first to employ synthesizers in a film score (_[On Her
Majesty's Secret Service](/wiki/On_Her_Majesty%27s_Secret_Service_\(film\) "On
Her Majesty's Secret Service \(film\)")_, also 1969),[15] and to make wide use
of pop artists and songs in _Midnight Cowboy_.[16] Because Barry provided not
just the main title theme but the complete soundtrack
[score](/wiki/Sheet_music "Sheet music"), his music often enhanced the
critical reception of a film, notably in _Midnight Cowboy_ , the first remake
of _[King Kong](/wiki/King_Kong_\(1976_film\) "King Kong \(1976 film\)")_
(1976), _[Out of Africa](/wiki/Out_of_Africa_\(film\) "Out of Africa
\(film\)")_ (1985), and _[Dances with Wolves](/wiki/Dances_with_Wolves "Dances
with Wolves")_ (1990). Barry would often watch films and would note down with
pen and paper what worked or what did not.[5]

Barry composed the theme for the TV series _[The
Persuaders!](/wiki/The_Persuaders! "The Persuaders!")_ (1971), also known as
_The Unlucky Heroes_ , in which [Tony Curtis](/wiki/Tony_Curtis "Tony Curtis")
and [Roger Moore](/wiki/Roger_Moore "Roger Moore") were paired as rich
playboys solving crimes.[17] The instrumental recording features the
[Cimbalom](/wiki/Cimbalom "Cimbalom") (which Barry also used for _[The Ipcress
File](/wiki/The_Ipcress_File_\(film\) "The Ipcress File \(film\)")_ (1965) and
other themes) and [Moog synthesizers](/wiki/Moog_synthesizer "Moog
synthesizer"). The theme was a hit single in many European countries
(including France, Germany, and the Benelux states), contributing to the cult
status of the series in Europe, and the record featured Barry's _The Girl with
the Sun in Her Hair_ on the B side, an instrumental piece featured in a long
running TV advert for [Sunsilk](/wiki/Sunsilk "Sunsilk") shampoo. Barry also
wrote the scores to a number of musicals, including the 1965 _[Passion Flower
Hotel](/wiki/Passion_Flower_Hotel "Passion Flower Hotel")_ (lyrics by [Trevor
Peacock](/wiki/Trevor_Peacock "Trevor Peacock")), the successful 1974 West End
show _[Billy](/wiki/Billy_\(musical\) "Billy \(musical\)")_ (lyrics by [Don
Black](/wiki/Don_Black_\(lyricist\) "Don Black \(lyricist\)")),[18] and two
major [Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_musical "Broadway musical") flops, _[Lolita,
My Love](/wiki/Lolita,_My_Love "Lolita, My Love")_ (1971), with [Alan Jay
Lerner](/wiki/Alan_Jay_Lerner "Alan Jay Lerner") as lyricist, and _[The Little
Prince and the Aviator](/wiki/The_Little_Prince_and_the_Aviator "The Little
Prince and the Aviator")_ (1981), again with lyricist Don Black.

In 2001, the [University of York](/wiki/University_of_York "University of
York") conferred an honorary degree on Barry, and in 2002 he was named an
Honorary [Freeman](/wiki/Freedom_of_the_City "Freedom of the City") of the
City of York.[19][20]

During 2006, Barry was the executive producer on an album entitled _Here 's to
the Heroes_ by the Australian ensemble [The Ten Tenors](/wiki/The_Ten_Tenors
"The Ten Tenors"). The album features a number of songs Barry wrote in
collaboration with his lyricist friend, Don Black. Barry and Black also
composed one of the songs on [Shirley Bassey](/wiki/Shirley_Bassey "Shirley
Bassey")'s 2009 album, _The Performance_. The song, entitled "Our Time Is
Now", is the first written by the duo for Bassey since "[Diamonds Are
Forever](/wiki/Diamonds_Are_Forever_\(soundtrack\) "Diamonds Are Forever
\(soundtrack\)")".[21]

### _James Bond_
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: James Bond series")]

After the success of _Dr. No_ , Barry was hired to compose and perform eleven
of the next fourteen _[James Bond](/wiki/James_Bond_in_film "James Bond in
film")_ films ([Monty Norman](/wiki/Monty_Norman "Monty Norman") is legally
recognised as the composer of the "[James Bond Theme](/wiki/James_Bond_Theme
"James Bond Theme")").[22]

In his tenure with the film series, Barry's music, variously brassy and moody,
achieved very wide appeal. For _From Russia with Love_ he composed "007", an
alternative James Bond signature theme, which is featured in four other Bond
films (_Thunderball_ , _You Only Live Twice_ , _Diamonds Are Forever_ and
_Moonraker_). The theme "Stalking", for the teaser sequence of _From Russia
with Love_ , was covered by colleague [Marvin Hamlisch](/wiki/Marvin_Hamlisch
"Marvin Hamlisch") for _[The Spy Who Loved
Me](/wiki/The_Spy_Who_Loved_Me_\(film\) "The Spy Who Loved Me \(film\)")_
(1977). (The music and lyrics for _From Russia with Love '_s title song were
written by [Lionel Bart](/wiki/Lionel_Bart "Lionel Bart"), whose musical
theatre credits included _Oliver!_) Barry also contributed indirectly to the
soundtrack of the spoof version of _[Casino
Royale](/wiki/Casino_Royale_\(1967_film\) "Casino Royale \(1967 film\)")_
(1967): his _[Born Free](/wiki/Born_Free "Born Free")_ theme appears briefly
in the opening sequence.

In _[Goldfinger](/wiki/Goldfinger_\(film\) "Goldfinger \(film\)")_ (1964), he
perfected the "Bond sound", a heady mixture of brass, jazz elements and
sensuous melodies. There is even an element of Barry's jazz roots in the big-
band track "Into Miami", which follows the title credits and accompanies the
film's iconic image of the camera lens zooming toward the Fontainebleau Hotel
in [Miami Beach](/wiki/Miami_Beach "Miami Beach"). A side note is that [Jimmy
Page](/wiki/Jimmy_Page "Jimmy Page"), worked as a session guitarist at the
time, and was a part of the recording sessions for the "Goldfinger"
soundtrack.[23] For Bond films, session musicians such as Page were relegated
to the instrumental/score version of songs, while the main musicians (on
Goldfinger: [Vic Flick](/wiki/Vic_Flick "Vic Flick")) were given the main film
theme song to record (featured at the beginning of the movie).[24] Leaving
Page as a background acoustic contributor to Flick on the instrumental version
of the song.

Barry's love for the Russian romantic composers is often reflected in his
music; in his Bond scores he unites this with brass-heavy jazz writing. His
use of strings, lyricism, half-diminished chords, and complex key shifting
provides melancholy contrast-often heard in variations of the title songs as
integrally infused with the plot development.[25]

As Barry matured, the Bond scores became more lushly melodic (along with other
scores of his such as _[Out of Africa](/wiki/Out_of_Africa_\(film\) "Out of
Africa \(film\)")_), as in _[Moonraker](/wiki/Moonraker_\(film\) "Moonraker
\(film\)")_ (1979) and _[Octopussy](/wiki/Octopussy "Octopussy")_ (1983).
Barry's score for _A View to a Kill_ was traditional, but his collaboration
with [Duran Duran](/wiki/Duran_Duran "Duran Duran") for the [title
song](/wiki/A_View_to_a_Kill_\(song\) "A View to a Kill \(song\)") was
contemporary and reached number one in the United States and number two in the
[UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"). Both _A View to
a Kill_ and _[The Living Daylights](/wiki/The_Living_Daylights_\(soundtrack\)
"The Living Daylights \(soundtrack\)")_ theme by [a-ha](/wiki/A-ha "A-ha")
blended the pop music style of the bands with Barry's orchestration. In 2006,
a-ha's [Pal Waaktaar](/wiki/Pal_Waaktaar "Pal Waaktaar") complimented Barry's
contributions: "I loved the stuff he added to the track, I mean it gave it
this really cool string arrangement. That's when for me it started to sound
like a Bond thing."[26]

Barry's last score for the Bond series was _[The Living
Daylights](/wiki/The_Living_Daylights "The Living Daylights")_ (1987),
[Timothy Dalton](/wiki/Timothy_Dalton "Timothy Dalton")'s first film in the
series with Barry making a cameo appearance as a conductor in the film.[27]
Barry was intended to score _[Licence to Kill](/wiki/Licence_to_Kill "Licence
to Kill")_ (1989) but was recovering from throat surgery at the time and it
was considered unsafe to fly him to London to complete the score. The score
was completed by [Michael Kamen](/wiki/Michael_Kamen "Michael Kamen").[28]

[David Arnold](/wiki/David_Arnold "David Arnold"), a British composer, saw the
result of two years' work in 1997 with the release of _Shaken and Stirred: The
David Arnold James Bond Project_ , an album of new versions of the themes from
various James Bond films. Arnold thanks Barry in the sleeve notes, referring
to him as "the Guvnor". Almost all of the tracks were John Barry compositions,
and the revision of his work met with his approval – he contacted [Barbara
Broccoli](/wiki/Barbara_Broccoli "Barbara Broccoli"), producer of the then
upcoming _[Tomorrow Never Dies](/wiki/Tomorrow_Never_Dies "Tomorrow Never
Dies")_ , to recommend Arnold as the film's composer.[29] Arnold also went on
to score four subsequent Bond films: _[The World Is Not
Enough](/wiki/The_World_Is_Not_Enough "The World Is Not Enough")_ , _[Die
Another Day](/wiki/Die_Another_Day "Die Another Day")_ , _[Casino
Royale](/wiki/Casino_Royale_\(2006_film\) "Casino Royale \(2006 film\)")_ and
_[Quantum of Solace](/wiki/Quantum_of_Solace "Quantum of Solace")_.

Sole compositional credit for the "James Bond Theme" is attributed to [Monty
Norman](/wiki/Monty_Norman "Monty Norman"), who was contracted as composer for
_Dr. No_. Some 30 years later, in 2001, the disputed authorship of the theme
was examined legally in the High Court in London after Norman sued _[The
Sunday Times](/wiki/The_Sunday_Times_\(UK\) "The Sunday Times \(UK\)")_ for
publishing an article in 1997 in which Barry was named as the true composer;
Barry testified for the defence.[30][31]

In court, Barry testified that he had been handed a musical manuscript of a
work by Norman (meant to become the theme) and that he was to arrange it
musically, and that he composed additional music and arranged the "James Bond
Theme". The court was also told that Norman received sole credit because of
his prior contract with the producers. Barry said that a deal was struck
whereby he would receive a flat fee of £250 and Norman would receive the
songwriting credit.[32] Barry said that he had accepted the deal with United
Artists Head of Music Noel Rogers because it would help his career. Despite
these claims the jury ruled unanimously in favour of Norman.[32]

On 7 September 2006, John Barry publicly defended his authorship of the theme
on the [Steve Wright](/wiki/Steve_Wright_\(DJ\) "Steve Wright \(DJ\)") show on
[BBC Radio 2](/wiki/BBC_Radio_2 "BBC Radio 2").[33]

### Personal life and
death[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Personal life and death")]

Barry was married four times. His first three marriages, to Barbara Pickard
(1959–63), [Jane Birkin](/wiki/Jane_Birkin "Jane Birkin") (1965–68), and Jane
Sidey (1969–78) all ended in divorce.[7] He was married to his fourth wife,
Laurie, from January 1978[7] until his death. The couple had a son,
Jonpatrick. Barry had three daughters, Suzanne (Susie) with his first wife,
Barbara, [Kate](/wiki/Kate_Barry_\(photographer\) "Kate Barry
\(photographer\)") with his second wife, Jane, and Sian from a relationship
with Ulla Larson between the first two marriages.[4] Suzy Barry, who is
married to BBC business journalist [Simon Jack](/wiki/Simon_Jack "Simon
Jack"), is the mother of his two granddaughters, Phoebe and Florence Ingleby.

In 1975 Barry moved to California. A British judge later accused him of
emigrating to avoid paying [£](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling")134,000
due the [Inland Revenue](/wiki/Inland_Revenue "Inland Revenue").[7] The matter
was resolved in the late 1980s and Barry was able to return to the UK.[7] He
subsequently lived for many years in the United States, mainly in [Oyster
Bay](/wiki/Oyster_Bay_\(hamlet\),_New_York "Oyster Bay \(hamlet\), New York"),
New York, in [Centre Island](/wiki/Centre_Island,_New_York "Centre Island, New
York") on [Long Island](/wiki/Long_Island "Long Island"), from 1980.[4][34]

Barry suffered a [rupture of the oesophagus](/wiki/Boerhaave_syndrome
"Boerhaave syndrome") in 1988, following a toxic reaction to a health tonic he
had consumed. The incident rendered him unable to work for two years and left
him vulnerable to [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia").[35]

Barry died of a heart attack on 30 January 2011 at his Oyster Bay home, aged
77.[36][37]

A memorial concert took place on 20 June 2011 at the [Royal Albert
Hall](/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall "Royal Albert Hall") in London where the [Royal
Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Royal_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Royal Philharmonic
Orchestra"), [Shirley Bassey](/wiki/Shirley_Bassey "Shirley Bassey"),
[Rumer](/wiki/Rumer_\(musician\) "Rumer \(musician\)"), [David
Arnold](/wiki/David_Arnold "David Arnold"), [Wynne Evans](/wiki/Wynne_Evans
"Wynne Evans") and others performed Barry's music.[38] [Sir George
Martin](/wiki/George_Martin "George Martin"), [Sir Michael
Parkinson](/wiki/Michael_Parkinson "Michael Parkinson"), [Don
Black](/wiki/Don_Black_\(lyricist\) "Don Black \(lyricist\)"), [Timothy
Dalton](/wiki/Timothy_Dalton "Timothy Dalton") and others also contributed to
the celebration of his life and work.[36][38][39] The event was sponsored by
the [Royal College of Music](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Music "Royal College of
Music") through a grant by the [Broccoli](/wiki/Albert_R._Broccoli "Albert R.
Broccoli") Foundation.[40]

## Awards and
nominations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Awards and nominations")]

In 1999 Barry was made an [Officer of the Order of the British
Empire](/wiki/Officer_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire "Officer of the Order
of the British Empire") (OBE) at [Buckingham Palace](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace
"Buckingham Palace") for services to music, and received the [BAFTA Academy
Fellowship Award](/wiki/BAFTA_Academy_Fellowship_Award "BAFTA Academy
Fellowship Award") in 2005.[39][41] In 2005, the [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute") ranked
Barry's score for _Out of Africa_ No. 15 on [their list of the greatest film
scores](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years_of_Film_Scores "AFI's 100 Years of Film
Scores").[42] His scores for the following films were also nominated:

  * _Goldfinger_ (1964)
  * _[Born Free](/wiki/Born_Free "Born Free")_ (1966)

###
Singles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Singles")]

(Excludes co-composed hits, e.g. [Duran Duran](/wiki/Duran_Duran "Duran
Duran")'s _[A View to a Kill](/wiki/A_View_to_a_Kill_\(song\) "A View to a
Kill \(song\)")_)

  * "Hit and Miss" as The John Barry Seven plus Four, UK#10 (first charted 1960)
  * "Beat for Beatniks" as The John Barry Orchestra, UK#40 (1960)
  * "Never Let Go" as The John Barry Orchestra, UK#49 (1960)
  * "Blueberry Hill" as The John Barry Orchestra, UK#34 (1960)
  * "Walk Don't Run" as The John Barry Seven, UK#11 (1960)
  * "Black Stockings" as The John Barry Seven, UK#27 (1960)
  * "[The Magnificent Seven](/wiki/The_Magnificent_Seven "The Magnificent Seven")" as The John Barry Seven, UK#45 (1961)
  * "Cutty Sark" as The John Barry Seven, UK#35 (1962)
  * "The [James Bond Theme](/wiki/James_Bond_Theme "James Bond Theme")" as The John Barry Orchestra, UK#13 (1962)
  * "From Russia with Love" as The John Barry Orchestra, UK#39 (1963)
  * "Theme from 'The Persuaders'" as John Barry, UK#13 (1971)

His four highest-charting hits all spent more than 10 weeks in the UK top 50.

### Sampled by other
artists[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Barry_\(composer\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Sampled by other artists")]

Barry's work began to be sampled in the 1990s by artists such as [Dr.
Dre](/wiki/Dr._Dre "Dr. Dre") and [Wu-Tang Clan](/wiki/Wu-Tang_Clan "Wu-Tang
Clan"), with his "[James Bond Theme](/wiki/James_Bond_Theme "James Bond
Theme")" being sampled by performers as diverse as [Bonobo](/wiki/Bonobo
"Bonobo"), [Gang Starr](/wiki/Gang_Starr "Gang Starr") and [Junior
Reid](/wiki/Junior_Reid "Junior Reid"). [Fatboy Slim](/wiki/Fatboy_Slim
"Fatboy Slim") used the opening guitars from "Beat Girl (Main Title)" for
"[Rockafeller Skank](/wiki/Rockafeller_Skank "Rockafeller Skank")" from his
album, _[You've Come a Long Way, Baby](/wiki/You%27ve_Come_a_Long_Way,_Baby
"You've Come a Long Way, Baby")_ (1998). [The Sneaker
Pimps](/wiki/The_Sneaker_Pimps "The Sneaker Pimps") also sampled "Golden Girl"
on their single "[6 Underground](/wiki/6_Underground "6 Underground")" (1996).
Additionally, "You Only Live Twice" was heavily sampled on
"[Millennium](/wiki/Millennium_\(song\) "Millennium \(song\)")" from [Robbie
Williams](/wiki/Robbie_Williams "Robbie Williams")' second album, _[I've Been
Expecting You](/wiki/I%27ve_Been_Expecting_You "I've Been Expecting You")_.
Barry was set to compose _[Thomas and the Magic
Railroad](/wiki/Thomas_and_the_Magic_Railroad "Thomas and the Magic
Railroad")_ but left due to scheduling conflicts.[48]
